On Differential Privacy for Federated Learning in Wireless Systems with Multiple Base Stations

Nima Tavangaran   Mingzhe Chen   Zhaohui Yang

Abstract

In this work, we consider a federated learning model in a wireless system with multiple base stations and inter-cell interference. We apply a differential private scheme to transmit information from users to their corresponding base station during the learning phase. We show the convergence behavior of the learning process by deriving an upper bound on its optimality gap. Furthermore, we define an optimization problem to reduce this upper bound and the total privacy leakage. To find the locally optimal solutions of this problem, we first propose an algorithm that schedules the resource blocks and users. We then extend this scheme to reduce the total privacy leakage by optimizing the differential privacy artificial noise. We apply the solutions of these two procedures as parameters of a federated learning system. In this setting, we assume that each user is equipped with a classifier. Moreover, the communication cells are assumed to have mostly fewer resource blocks than numbers of users. The simulation results show that our proposed scheduler improves the average accuracy of the predictions compared with a random scheduler. Furthermore, its extended version with noise optimizer significantly reduces the amount of privacy leakage.

Index Terms:
Differential privacy, federated learning, neural networks, wireless channel, multiple base stations.

I Introduction

Machine Learning (ML) systems are expected to play an important role in future mobile communication standards [1]. With increasing applications of ML schemes in wireless systems, new technologies are emerging to enhance the performance of such systems. On the other hand the wireless technology itself can also be deployed to enhance the ML procedures [2]. Among possible candidates, Federated Learning (FL) has been shown to have considerable promise [3, 4, 5] and has the potential to benefit from wireless communication.

FL solves several issues of centralized ML systems by distributing the learning task among several edge devices. One advantage of using an FL system, which makes it a good fit in a wireless setting, is that edge devices do not need to transmit their local datasets to the server. This reduces the amount of wireless resources that is required for accomplishing the given ML task. Apart from this, the privacy of each edge device is not completely compromised since the server does not have a direct access to the data [6].

FL schemes operating over wireless networks have been extensively researched in recent years; see for example [7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13]. In [8], the authors studied the effects of wireless parameters on the FL process. They derived an upper bound on the optimality gap of the convergence terms and proposed an optimization problem to minimize the upper bound by considering wireless parameters like resource allocation, user scheduling, and packet error rate. Some other works that studied the communication aspects of FL are [14, 15, 16]. Moreover, FL with several layers of aggregation or with hierarchy has been studied in [17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22].

Although the training data of each device in FL is not transmitted to the server, yet a function of the local model (query) is still sent to the server. It has been shown that this local model might leak some information about the training data [23]. To mitigate this drawback, FL has been extensively studied together with a privacy preserving scheme called Differential Privacy (DP) [24].

DP-based schemes follow the principle of not being adversely affected much by having one’s data used in any analysis [25]. This powerful notion is well established and is applied in industry. To realize a DP-based FL system, each edge device adds some artificial noise to its transmitting information. This noise provides a certain amount of privacy depending on the noise power and sensitivity of the query function.

DP based FL and its convergence behavior have been extensively studied; see for example [26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 31, 32]. In this regard, the work in [26] addresses the privacy implementation challenges through a combination of zero-concentrated differential privacy, local gradient perturbation and secure aggregation.[30] considers the resource allocation and user scheduling to minimize the FL training delay under the constraint of performance and DP requirements. Finally, [32] presents a closed-form global loss and privacy leakage of a DP-based FL system and then minimizes the loss and privacy leakage.

However, none of these works consider a joint learning and resource allocation scheme for DP-based FL that considers the effects of inter-cell interference as well. In this paper, we adapt the framework in [8] and consider a wireless FL system in a multiple base station scenario. Additionally, we consider DP noise added to the gradients [26] and combine this approach with resource scheduling.

The goal of the FL system here is to train a global model for a given predictor. We introduce an iterative DP-based FL scheme with two levels of aggregation (Algorithm 1) and then derive an upper bound on the optimality gap of its convergence terms (Theorem 1).

We then propose an optimization problem whose goal is to improve the convergence of the upper bound on the optimality gap of Algorithm 1 and simultaneously reduce the total privacy leakage. In this regard, the optimization problem is with respect to certain variables like user and resource scheduling, uplink transmit powers, and the amount of DP noise that is applied by each user to its transmitting information.

Since the proposed optimization problem is a non-linear multi-variable mixed integer programming, we divide it into two simpler schemes.

First, we present a suboptimal approach to minimize the objective function only with respect to resource scheduling variables in a sequential manner, i.e., cell by cell. This reduces the original problem to a linear integer programming task and substantially simplifies the implementation. We call this scheme also the optimal scheduler (OptSched). Since this approach performs sequentially from one cell to another one, the amounts of optimal transmit power should be adjusted carefully due to the effects of inter-cell interference. To tackle this problem, we introduce a procedure to determine the users’ optimal transmit powers by solving a simple optimization problem.

Next, we enhance the OptSched scheme by further minimizing the objective function of the proposed optimization problem with respect to the DP noise. This leads us to a convex optimization problem with respect to the DP noise standard deviations. We call this extended scheme the optimal scheduler with DP optimizer (OptSched+DP).

We present all the numerical optimizations and benchmarking results. In this regard, we apply Python optimization packages like CVXPY, CVXOPT, GLPK, and ECOS [33, 34, 35, 36, 37]. The numerical results show that our proposed schemes (OptSched and OptSched+DP) reduce the objective function of the optimization task substantially compared with the case in which we randomly allocate the resources and apply the DP noise.

Next, we apply these (sub-)optimal parameters to our iterative learning scheme (Algorithm 1). In this regard, each user is equipped with a fully connected multi-layer neural network as a classifier. Furthermore, we assume that communication cells have mainly more users than available resource blocks. This is a legitimate assumption due to the bandwidth limitation. We then perform simulations to measure the accuracy, loss, and the amount of the privacy leakage in such a system for the proposed algorithms. To realize the simulations, we apply the TensorFlow, NumPy, and Matplotlib packages [38, 39, 40].

The simulations show that the OptSched scheme predominantly improves the classification accuracy by scheduling the users who have larger data chunks and better uplink channels. The OptSched+DP scheme, on the other hand, achieves a significant reduction in privacy leakage of individual users by systematically adjusting the DP noise power and moderately sacrificing accuracy.

II System Model

We begin this section by reviewing some preliminary notions on DP that are required in this work. The complete list of definitions can be found in [24, 25, 41].

II-A Differential Privacy Model

Let a data universe 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} and the distribution PXsubscript𝑃𝑋P_{X} on it be given. Assume that a database is denoted by a matrix 𝑿∈𝒳K×m𝑿superscript𝒳𝐾𝑚\bm{X}\in\mathcal{X}^{K\times m} and contains K𝐾K rows of independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) m𝑚m-dimensional samples (row vectors). Two databases 𝑿,𝑿~∈𝒳K×m𝑿~𝑿superscript𝒳𝐾𝑚\bm{X},\tilde{\bm{X}}\in\mathcal{X}^{K\times m} are called adjacent if they differ only in one row.

A query (mechanism) q:𝒳K×m→ℝd:𝑞→superscript𝒳𝐾𝑚superscriptℝ𝑑q:\mathcal{X}^{K\times m}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d} is a function which takes a database 𝑿∈𝒳K×m𝑿superscript𝒳𝐾𝑚\bm{X}\in\mathcal{X}^{K\times m} as input and gives a d𝑑d-dimensional output. If the output of the query contains randomness then it is called a randomized mechanism.

In the following, we introduce the notion of privacy for randomized mechanisms, which are defined on a given set of databases 𝒳K×msuperscript𝒳𝐾𝑚\mathcal{X}^{K\times m}.

Definition 1.

A randomized mechanism 𝔐:𝒳K×m→ℝd:𝔐→superscript𝒳𝐾𝑚superscriptℝ𝑑\mathfrak{M}:\mathcal{X}^{K\times m}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d} is said to be (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-Differentially Private, or for short (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP, if for every adjacent 𝐗,𝐗~∈𝒳K×m𝐗~𝐗superscript𝒳𝐾𝑚\bm{X},\tilde{\bm{X}}\in\mathcal{X}^{K\times m}, we have that

Pr​(𝔐​(𝑿)∈𝒲)≤eϵ​Pr​(𝔐​(𝑿~)∈𝒲)+δPr𝔐𝑿𝒲superscripteitalic-ϵPr𝔐~𝑿𝒲𝛿\displaystyle\mathrm{Pr}\big{(}\mathfrak{M}(\bm{X})\in\mathcal{W}\big{)}\leq\mathrm{e}^{\epsilon}\,\mathrm{Pr}\big{(}\mathfrak{M}(\tilde{\bm{X}})\in\mathcal{W}\big{)}+\delta (1)

holds for any 𝒲⊂ℝd𝒲superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{W}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}.

In this work, we apply a relaxed version of the (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP that is more suitable for Gaussian mechanisms.

Definition 2.

A randomized mechanism 𝔐:𝒳K×m→ℝd:𝔐→superscript𝒳𝐾𝑚superscriptℝ𝑑\mathfrak{M}:\mathcal{X}^{K\times m}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d} is said to be ρ𝜌\rho-zero-Concentrated Differentially Private (CDP), or for short ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP, if

Dα​(𝔐​(𝑿)∥𝔐​(𝑿~))≤ρ​αsubscriptD𝛼conditional𝔐𝑿𝔐~𝑿𝜌𝛼\displaystyle\mathrm{D}_{\alpha}\big{(}\mathfrak{M}(\bm{X})\,\|\,\mathfrak{M}(\tilde{\bm{X}})\big{)}\leq\rho\alpha (2)

holds for every adjacent 𝐗,𝐗~∈𝒳K×m𝐗~𝐗superscript𝒳𝐾𝑚\bm{X},\tilde{\bm{X}}\in\mathcal{X}^{K\times m} and all α∈(1,∞)𝛼1\alpha\in(1,\infty), where DαsubscriptD𝛼\mathrm{D}_{\alpha} is the α𝛼\alpha-Rényi divergence [41].

II-B Federated Learning Model

Based on the notions from previous section, we introduce our privacy preserving FL model for a system with multiple base stations. Let a collection of base stations denoted by the set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} be given such that they can communicate with each other through a main server. Assume that each base station s∈𝒮𝑠𝒮s\in\mathcal{S} serves a set of edge devices (users) denoted by 𝒰ssubscript𝒰𝑠\mathcal{U}_{s}, where the users in 𝒰ssubscript𝒰𝑠\mathcal{U}_{s} have some arbitrary order. Let Ussubscript𝑈𝑠U_{s} denote the size of this set.

We assume that each user i∈𝒰s𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠i\in\mathcal{U}_{s} assigned to the base station s𝑠s has access to a database

𝑿s,isubscript𝑿𝑠𝑖\displaystyle\bm{X}_{s,i} ≔(𝒙s,i(1),𝒙s,i(2),…,𝒙s,i(Ks,i))⊺∈ℝKs,i×m,≔absentsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒙𝑠𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑠𝑖2…superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑠𝑖subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖⊺superscriptℝsubscript𝐾𝑠𝑖𝑚\displaystyle\coloneqq\big{(}\bm{x}_{s,i}^{(1)},\bm{x}_{s,i}^{(2)},\ldots,\bm{x}_{s,i}^{(K_{s,i})}\big{)}^{\intercal}\in\mathbb{R}^{K_{s,i}\times m},

where Ks,isubscript𝐾𝑠𝑖K_{s,i} is the number of samples (row vectors) in the database 𝑿s,isubscript𝑿𝑠𝑖\bm{X}_{s,i}. Each row of the above matrix, say 𝒙s,i(k)superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑠𝑖𝑘\bm{x}_{s,i}^{(k)}, is an m𝑚m-dimensional data sample given by

𝒙s,i(k)≔(xs,i(k)​(1),xs,i(k)​(2),…,xs,i(k)​(m−1),ys,i(k)),≔superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑠𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑠𝑖𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑠𝑖𝑘2…superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑠𝑖𝑘𝑚1superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑠𝑖𝑘\displaystyle\bm{x}_{s,i}^{(k)}\coloneqq\big{(}x_{s,i}^{(k)}(1),x_{s,i}^{(k)}(2),\ldots,x_{s,i}^{(k)}(m-1),y_{s,i}^{(k)}\big{)},

where the first m−1𝑚1m-1 elements are the inputs and the last entry ys,i(k)superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑠𝑖𝑘y_{s,i}^{(k)} is the output of the training data.

In the first step of the FL scheme at round t=1𝑡1t=1, the main server broadcasts a weight vector 𝒘(t)∈ℝdsuperscript𝒘𝑡superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{w}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} to all base stations. This vector is called the global model and can be initialized randomly. Then, each base station s𝑠s transmits this model to all of its edge devices. Let only a subset of the users in each cell are active and participate in the learning process. We denote the active users in cell s𝑠s by:

𝒂s≔(as,i)i∈𝒰s∈{0,1}Us,≔subscript𝒂𝑠subscriptsubscript𝑎𝑠𝑖𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠superscript01subscript𝑈𝑠\displaystyle\bm{a}_{s}\coloneqq(a_{s,i})_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}\in\{0,1\}^{U_{s}}, (3)

where as,i=1subscript𝑎𝑠𝑖1a_{s,i}=1 indicates that user i∈𝒰s𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠i\in\mathcal{U}_{s} is scheduled [8] to participate in the learning process and as,i=0subscript𝑎𝑠𝑖0a_{s,i}=0, otherwise.

Fig. 1 shows an example of a model with multiple base stations. In this example, all users of cell s𝑠s (depicted on the bottom of the figure), are scheduled to participate in the FL process and receive the vector 𝒘(t)superscript𝒘𝑡\bm{w}^{(t)}.

Each scheduled user computes a local loss function depending on the ML algorithm that is applied in the system. We denote the loss function of a user i∈𝒰s𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠i\in\mathcal{U}_{s} by l​(𝒘(t),𝒙s,i(k))𝑙superscript𝒘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑠𝑖𝑘l(\bm{w}^{(t)},\bm{x}_{s,i}^{(k)}), which is a function of the global model and its training sample. The main reason of applying Gaussian noise is that it gives tight bounds when applied with zCDP [41]. The following vector denotes the noise standard deviations of the users in the cell s𝑠s:

where λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0 is the learning step size. It then transmits its updated model111For the sake of simplicity, we consider only a single local update at each edge device in each round and also consider the batch gradient descent. 𝒘s,i(t+1)superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑠𝑖𝑡1\bm{w}_{s,i}^{(t+1)} to its corresponding base station s𝑠s.

In the next step, base station s𝑠s aggregates all received updated models 𝒘s,i(t+1)superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑠𝑖𝑡1\bm{w}_{s,i}^{(t+1)} as given below:

𝒘s(t+1)≔1∑i∈𝒰sKs,i​as,i​∑i∈𝒰sKs,i​as,i​𝒘s,i(t+1),≔superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑠𝑡11subscript𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖subscript𝑎𝑠𝑖subscript𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖subscript𝑎𝑠𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑠𝑖𝑡1\displaystyle\bm{w}_{s}^{(t+1)}\coloneqq\frac{1}{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}K_{s,i}a_{s,i}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}K_{s,i}a_{s,i}\bm{w}_{s,i}^{(t+1)}, (8)

where as,isubscript𝑎𝑠𝑖a_{s,i} is the scheduling parameter and was defined as an element of the vector 𝒂ssubscript𝒂𝑠\bm{a}_{s} in Eq. (3).

Consequently, all base stations send their aggregated models to the main server. There, the global model at round t+1𝑡1t+1 is computed as follows

𝒘(t+1)≔1Ka​∑s∈𝒮∑i∈𝒰sKs,i​as,i​𝒘s(t+1),≔superscript𝒘𝑡11subscript𝐾asubscript𝑠𝒮subscript𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖subscript𝑎𝑠𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑠𝑡1\displaystyle\bm{w}^{(t+1)}\coloneqq\frac{1}{K_{\mathrm{a}}}\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}K_{s,i}a_{s,i}\bm{w}_{s}^{(t+1)}, (9)

where

is the total number of training samples of all scheduled users.

Next, the main server broadcasts the new global model 𝒘(t+1)superscript𝒘𝑡1\bm{w}^{(t+1)} to the base stations where it is then forwarded further to their corresponding users. This process continues for a given number of T𝑇T iterations. Algorithm 1 summarizes these steps, where (𝒂s,𝝈s)s∈𝒮subscriptsubscript𝒂𝑠subscript𝝈𝑠𝑠𝒮(\bm{a}_{s},\bm{\sigma}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}} are assumed to be shared with all participants at the beginning of the learning process.

One difference between Algorithm 1 and other approaches like e.g. the FL schemes in [26, 8] is that here the aggregation is done in two steps. Additionally, the noise standard deviations σs,isubscript𝜎𝑠𝑖\sigma_{s,i} at users are not necessarily identical here and a joint optimal user scheduling and DP noise adjustment is possible.

To characterize the DP noise, we need to make the following assumption which can be achieved in practice by weight clipping [43, 26].

Assumption 1.

The gradients of the local loss functions are always upper bounded:

‖∇l​(𝒘,𝒙)‖2≤L.subscriptnorm∇𝑙𝒘𝒙2𝐿\displaystyle\|\nabla l(\bm{w},\bm{x})\|_{2}\leq L.

In [26], it was shown that if Assumption 1 holds, then after T𝑇T iterations, a mechanism like 𝔐s,i(t)​(𝑿s,i)superscriptsubscript𝔐𝑠𝑖𝑡subscript𝑿𝑠𝑖\mathfrak{M}_{s,i}^{(t)}(\bm{X}_{s,i}) is ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP where

ρ=2​T​(LKs,i​σs,i)2𝜌2𝑇superscript𝐿subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖subscript𝜎𝑠𝑖2\displaystyle\rho=2T\left(\frac{L}{K_{s,i}\sigma_{s,i}}\right)^{2} (11)

is the privacy leakage.

Note that the DP noise affects the convergence of the learning process as well. In Section III, we study the convergence behavior of Algorithm 1 with respect to the vector parameters 𝒂ssubscript𝒂𝑠\bm{a}_{s} and 𝝈ssubscript𝝈𝑠\bm{\sigma}_{s}.

III Convergence Analysis

In the following, we define the global loss as a function of local losses. We then derive an upper bound on the optimality gap that appears in each round of Algorithm 1.

The global loss function is computed over all base stations and is given by

f​(𝒘(t))≔1K​∑s∈𝒮∑i∈𝒰s∑k=1Ks,il​(𝒘(t),𝒙s,i(k)),≔𝑓superscript𝒘𝑡1𝐾subscript𝑠𝒮subscript𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑘1subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖𝑙superscript𝒘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑠𝑖𝑘\displaystyle f(\bm{w}^{(t)})\coloneqq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}\sum_{k=1}^{K_{s,i}}l(\bm{w}^{(t)},\bm{x}_{s,i}^{(k)}), (12)

where K=∑s∈𝒮∑i∈𝒰sKs,i𝐾subscript𝑠𝒮subscript𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖K=\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}K_{s,i} is the total number of samples (including scheduled or non-scheduled).

The following assumptions are necessary to analyze the global loss function f𝑓f and have been used before in the literature [44].

Assumption 2.

The loss function f:ℝd→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} has a minimum value, i.e., there exists an input vector 𝐰∗=arg⁡min𝐰∈ℝd⁡(f​(𝐰))superscript𝐰subscript𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑𝑓𝐰\bm{w}^{*}=\arg\min_{\bm{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}(f(\bm{w})).

Assumption 3.

The gradient ∇f​(𝐰)∇𝑓𝐰\nabla f(\bm{w}) is uniformly L𝐿L-Lipschitz continuous with respect to the model 𝐰𝐰\bm{w}, i.e.,

‖∇f​(𝒘)−∇f​(𝒘′)‖2≤L​‖𝒘−𝒘′‖2 for all ​𝒘,𝒘′∈ℝd.formulae-sequencesubscriptnorm∇𝑓𝒘∇𝑓superscript𝒘′2𝐿subscriptnorm𝒘superscript𝒘′2 for all 𝒘superscript𝒘′superscriptℝ𝑑\displaystyle\|\nabla f(\bm{w})-\nabla f(\bm{w}^{\prime})\|_{2}\leq L\|\bm{w}-\bm{w}^{\prime}\|_{2}\quad\text{ for all }\bm{w},\bm{w}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.
Assumption 4.

The loss function f:ℝd→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex, i.e.,

f​(𝒘)≥f​(𝒘′)+(𝒘−𝒘′)⊺​∇f​(𝒘′)+12​μ​‖𝒘−𝒘′‖22𝑓𝒘𝑓superscript𝒘′superscript𝒘superscript𝒘′⊺∇𝑓superscript𝒘′12𝜇superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒘superscript𝒘′22\displaystyle f(\bm{w})\geq f(\bm{w}^{\prime})+(\bm{w}-\bm{w}^{\prime})^{\intercal}\nabla f(\bm{w}^{\prime})+\frac{1}{2}\mu\|\bm{w}-\bm{w}^{\prime}\|_{2}^{2}

holds for all 𝐰,𝐰′∈ℝd𝐰superscript𝐰′superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{w},\bm{w}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Assumption 5.

The loss function f:ℝd→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is twice continuously differentiable. Then, Assumptions 3 and 4 are equivalent to the following:

μ​𝑰d⪯∇2f​(𝒘)⪯L​𝑰d for all ​𝒘∈ℝd.formulae-sequenceprecedes-or-equals𝜇subscript𝑰𝑑superscript∇2𝑓𝒘precedes-or-equals𝐿subscript𝑰𝑑 for all 𝒘superscriptℝ𝑑\displaystyle\mu\bm{I}_{d}\preceq\nabla^{2}f(\bm{w})\preceq L\bm{I}_{d}\qquad\text{ for all }\bm{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.
Assumption 6.

There exists constants ξ1≥0subscript𝜉10\xi_{1}\geq 0 and ξ2≥1subscript𝜉21\xi_{2}\geq 1, such that for any training sample 𝐱𝐱\bm{x} and model 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, the following inequality holds

‖∇l​(𝒘,𝒙)‖22≤ξ1+ξ2​‖∇f​(𝒘)‖22.superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑙𝒘𝒙22subscript𝜉1subscript𝜉2superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑓𝒘22\displaystyle\|\nabla l(\bm{w},\bm{x})\|_{2}^{2}\leq\xi_{1}+\xi_{2}\|\nabla f(\bm{w})\|_{2}^{2}.

Now, we are ready to derive an upper bound on the optimality gap of Algorithm 1.

Theorem 1.

Let Assumptions 2–6 hold. Then, the following upper bound on the optimality gap for Algorithm 1 holds:

𝔼​[f​(𝒘t+1)−f​(𝒘∗)]≤C1​𝔼​[f​(𝒘(t))−f​(𝒘∗)]+C2+C3,𝔼delimited-[]𝑓superscript𝒘𝑡1𝑓superscript𝒘subscript𝐶1𝔼delimited-[]𝑓superscript𝒘𝑡𝑓superscript𝒘subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶3\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\big{[}f(\bm{w}^{t+1})-f(\bm{w}^{*})\big{]}\leq C_{1}\mathbb{E}\Big{[}f(\bm{w}^{(t)})-f(\bm{w}^{*})\Big{]}+C_{2}+C_{3},

where the expectation is taken over the DP noise and

C1subscript𝐶1\displaystyle C_{1} =1−μL+4​ξ2K2​(∑s∈𝒮∑i∈𝒰sKs,i​(1−as,i))2,absent1𝜇𝐿4subscript𝜉2superscript𝐾2superscriptsubscript𝑠𝒮subscript𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖1subscript𝑎𝑠𝑖2\displaystyle=1-\frac{\mu}{L}+\frac{4\xi_{2}}{K^{2}}\bigg{(}\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}K_{s,i}\big{(}1-a_{s,i}\big{)}\bigg{)}^{2},
C2subscript𝐶2\displaystyle C_{2} =2​ξ1L​K2​(∑s∈𝒮∑i∈𝒰sKs,i​(1−as,i))2,absent2subscript𝜉1𝐿superscript𝐾2superscriptsubscript𝑠𝒮subscript𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖1subscript𝑎𝑠𝑖2\displaystyle=\frac{2\xi_{1}}{LK^{2}}\bigg{(}\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}K_{s,i}\big{(}1-a_{s,i}\big{)}\bigg{)}^{2},
C3subscript𝐶3\displaystyle C_{3} =d2​L​∑s∈𝒮∑i∈𝒰s(Ks,i​as,iKa​σs,i)2.absent𝑑2𝐿subscript𝑠𝒮subscript𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑠𝑖subscript𝑎𝑠𝑖subscript𝐾asubscript𝜎𝑠𝑖2\displaystyle=\frac{d}{2L}\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}\Big{(}\frac{K_{s,i}a_{s,i}}{K_{\mathrm{a}}}\sigma_{s,i}\Big{)}^{2}.
Proof.

The proof is provided in the Appendix. ∎

Theorem 1 shows that the expected difference between the global loss and the optimal value f​(𝒘∗)𝑓superscript𝒘f(\bm{w}^{*}) per iteration is upper bound by expressions that depend on C1subscript𝐶1C_{1}, C2subscript𝐶2C_{2}, and C3subscript𝐶3C_{3}. Hence, by lowering the values of C1subscript𝐶1C_{1}, C2subscript𝐶2C_{2}, and C3subscript𝐶3C_{3}, the convergence of Algorithm 1 should be improved. In addition, Theorem 1 shows that the upper bound on the optimality gap is influenced by the scheduling parameters as,isubscript𝑎𝑠𝑖a_{s,i} and DP noise standard deviations σs,isubscript𝜎𝑠𝑖\sigma_{s,i}. We also observe that the upper bound converges only if C1<1subscript𝐶11C_{1}<1. In Section IV, we design an optimal scheduler and a DP optimizer based on these variables and their effect on this upper bound.

IV Learning over Wireless Channels with Inter-cell Interference

In this section, we consider other wireless parameters of the communication system and connect them to the notion of learning. These wireless parameters include resource allocation, transmit power consumption, fading channels, inter-cell interference, and communication rate.

We assume that the users apply an Orthogonal Frequency-Division Multiple Access (OFDMA) technique in the uplink channel to transmit data to their corresponding base station. In this case, each edge device i∈𝒰s𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠i\in\mathcal{U}_{s} is assigned a resource block indexed by n∈[R]𝑛delimited-[]𝑅n\in[R] where R𝑅R is the total number of available uplink transmission resource blocks in each cell.

We define the uplink resource allocation matrix 𝑹ssubscript𝑹𝑠\bm{R}_{s} in a given cell s𝑠s as

𝑹s≔(rs,i(1),rs,i(2),…,rs,i(R))i∈𝒰s,≔subscript𝑹𝑠subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑠𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑠𝑖2…superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑠𝑖𝑅𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠\displaystyle\bm{R}_{s}\coloneqq\big{(}r_{s,i}^{(1)},r_{s,i}^{(2)},\dots,r_{s,i}^{(R)}\big{)}_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}, (13)

where rs,i(n)∈{0,1}superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑠𝑖𝑛01r_{s,i}^{(n)}\in\{0,1\}. Each row of this matrix represents the resource allocation for a user i∈𝒰s𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}. In this case, rs,i(n)=1superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑠𝑖𝑛1r_{s,i}^{(n)}=1 indicates that the edge device i∈𝒰s𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠i\in\mathcal{U}_{s} uses resource block n𝑛n in the uplink transmission and rs,i(n)=0superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑠𝑖𝑛0r_{s,i}^{(n)}=0, otherwise. Moreover, we assume that each active user (as,i=1subscript𝑎𝑠𝑖1a_{s,i}=1) is assigned only one resource block and inactive users (as,i=0subscript𝑎𝑠𝑖0a_{s,i}=0) are not assigned any resource block at all, i.e.,

∑n=1Rrs,i(n)=as,i,∀i∈𝒰s,s∈𝒮.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑠𝑖𝑛subscript𝑎𝑠𝑖formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠𝑠𝒮\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{R}r_{s,i}^{(n)}=a_{s,i},\forall i\in\mathcal{U}_{s},s\in\mathcal{S}. (14)

In addition, edge devices in a given cell s𝑠s do not interfere with each other, i.e.,

∑i∈𝒰srs,i(n)≤1,∀n∈[R],s∈𝒮.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑠𝑖𝑛1formulae-sequencefor-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑅𝑠𝒮\displaystyle\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}r_{s,i}^{(n)}\leq 1,\forall n\in[R],s\in\mathcal{S}. (15)

To be able to formulate the communication rate, we need first to define the transmit powers of the users. Let the uplink transmit power vector of all edge devices at a given cell s∈𝒮𝑠𝒮s\in\mathcal{S} be denoted by

𝒑s≔(ps,i)i∈𝒰s,≔subscript𝒑𝑠subscriptsubscript𝑝𝑠𝑖𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠\displaystyle\bm{p}_{s}\coloneqq(p_{s,i})_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}},

where ps,isubscript𝑝𝑠𝑖p_{s,i} denotes the transmit power of the user i∈𝒰s𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}. Moreover, the maximum transmit power of each user in any cell is denoted by Pmaxsubscript𝑃P_{\max}.

Another wireless parameter, which is of great importance in the considered system with multiple base stations, is the inter-cell interference. Let Is(n)​(s~)superscriptsubscript𝐼𝑠𝑛~𝑠I_{s}^{(n)}(\tilde{s}) denote the interference signal power [45] from the cell s~∈𝒮\{s}~𝑠\𝒮𝑠\tilde{s}\in\mathcal{S}\backslash\{s\} that affects the uplink signal received by the base station s𝑠s on the resource block n𝑛n. In this case, inequality (15) implies that Is(n)​(s~)superscriptsubscript𝐼𝑠𝑛~𝑠I_{s}^{(n)}(\tilde{s}) is a factor of the transmit power of only one user in the cell s~~𝑠\tilde{s} that transmits signals on the resource block n𝑛n. In other words, the received interference signal power can be formulated as

Is(n)​(s~)=∑i∈𝒰s~hs,i​rs~,i(n)​ps~,i.superscriptsubscript𝐼𝑠𝑛~𝑠subscript𝑖subscript𝒰~𝑠subscriptℎ𝑠𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑟~𝑠𝑖𝑛subscript𝑝~𝑠𝑖\displaystyle I_{s}^{(n)}(\tilde{s})=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{\tilde{s}}}h_{s,i}r_{\tilde{s},i}^{(n)}p_{\tilde{s},i}. (16)

The term hs,isubscriptℎ𝑠𝑖h_{s,i} in (16) is the channel gain between the user i∈𝒰s~𝑖subscript𝒰~𝑠i\in\mathcal{U}_{\tilde{s}} and the base station s𝑠s and can be computed by determining the pathloss [46]. The channel gain is given by

hs,i=l2​(c4​π​f)2​(1ds,i)3,subscriptℎ𝑠𝑖superscript𝑙2superscript𝑐4𝜋𝑓2superscript1subscript𝑑𝑠𝑖3\displaystyle h_{s,i}=l^{2}\Big{(}\frac{c}{4\pi f}\Big{)}^{2}\Big{(}\frac{1}{d_{s,i}}\Big{)}^{3}, (17)

where f𝑓f is the uplink center frequency, ds,isubscript𝑑𝑠𝑖d_{s,i} is the distance between the user i∈𝒰s~𝑖subscript𝒰~𝑠i\in\mathcal{U}_{\tilde{s}} and base station s𝑠s, l𝑙l is the output of a Rayleigh distribution with a unit scale parameter, and c𝑐c is the speed of light.

Fig. 2 illustrates an example of a wireless communication system with three base stations s,s′,𝑠superscript𝑠′s,s^{\prime}, and s′′superscript𝑠′′s^{\prime\prime} in the uplink stage. In this example, the received signals on the resource block n𝑛n at the base station s′superscript𝑠′s^{\prime} are affected by the interference signal power Is′(n)​(s)superscriptsubscript𝐼superscript𝑠′𝑛𝑠I_{s^{\prime}}^{(n)}(s) from cell s𝑠s. Furthermore, base station s′′superscript𝑠′′s^{\prime\prime} is affected by the interference signal power Is′′(n)​(s′)superscriptsubscript𝐼superscript𝑠′′𝑛superscript𝑠′I_{s^{\prime\prime}}^{(n)}(s^{\prime}) from cell s′superscript𝑠′s^{\prime}.

Let the uplink fading channel between each user i∈𝒰s𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠i\in\mathcal{U}_{s} and its corresponding base station s𝑠s be fixed and equal to hs,isubscriptℎ𝑠𝑖h_{s,i}. Also assume that the uplink bandwidth is denoted by B𝐵B. Furthermore, all participants are assumed to have perfect channel knowledge. It is known (see e.g. [45, 8]) that the maximum uplink communication rate between each user i∈𝒰s𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠i\in\mathcal{U}_{s} and its corresponding base station s𝑠s can be formulated as

cs,iUsuperscriptsubscript𝑐𝑠𝑖U\displaystyle c_{s,i}^{\mathrm{U}} ≔∑n=1Rrs,i(n)​B​log⁡(1+ps,i​hs,i∑s~∈𝒮\{s}Is(n)​(s~)+B​N0),≔absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑠𝑖𝑛𝐵1subscript𝑝𝑠𝑖subscriptℎ𝑠𝑖subscript~𝑠\𝒮𝑠superscriptsubscript𝐼𝑠𝑛~𝑠𝐵subscript𝑁0\displaystyle\coloneqq\sum_{n=1}^{R}r_{s,i}^{(n)}B\log\bigg{(}1+\frac{p_{s,i}h_{s,i}}{\sum_{\tilde{s}\in\mathcal{S}\backslash\{s\}}I_{s}^{(n)}(\tilde{s})+BN_{0}}\bigg{)}, (18)

where N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} is the thermal noise power spectral density. We assume that the minimum required uplink communication rate between each user and its base station is denoted by a constant Rminsubscript𝑅R_{\min}.

Before applying these wireless parameters in the learning process, we first need to introduce another measure based on the DP standard deviations (𝝈s)s∈𝒮subscriptsubscript𝝈𝑠𝑠𝒮(\bm{\sigma}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}}. In this regard, we define the total privacy leakage as follows:

2​T​L2​∑s∈𝒮∑i∈𝒰s(1Ks,i​σs,i)2​as,i.2𝑇superscript𝐿2subscript𝑠𝒮subscript𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠superscript1subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖subscript𝜎𝑠𝑖2subscript𝑎𝑠𝑖\displaystyle 2TL^{2}\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}\big{(}\frac{1}{K_{s,i}\sigma_{s,i}}\big{)}^{2}a_{s,i}. (19)

In this definition, the summands in (19) are computed by multiplying the privacy leakage given by (11) at each user with the scheduling variables as,isubscript𝑎𝑠𝑖a_{s,i}. Minimizing this measure reduces the individual privacy leakage as well. This improvement is due to the systematic adjustment of the DP noise power at each user. In this case, edge devices who have a larger number of samples Ks,isubscript𝐾𝑠𝑖K_{s,i} are assigned less DP noise power.

The parameters 𝑹ssubscript𝑹𝑠\bm{R}_{s} and 𝝈ssubscript𝝈𝑠\bm{\sigma}_{s} play a critical role in improving the convergence rate of Algorithm 1 (cf. Theorem 1) and reducing the total privacy leakage. Furthermore, the parameter 𝒑ssubscript𝒑𝑠\bm{p}_{s} is critical in establishing a reliable communication. By minimizing C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} with respect to these parameters, the upper bound on the optimality gap in Theorem 1 reduces and thus the convergence rate of the FL procedure should improve. To this end, it is sufficient to minimize only the expressions inside the squared term in C1subscript𝐶1C_{1}.

Therefore, we propose an optimization problem over the variables (𝑹s,𝒑s,𝝈s)s∈𝒮subscriptsubscript𝑹𝑠subscript𝒑𝑠subscript𝝈𝑠𝑠𝒮(\bm{R}_{s},\bm{p}_{s},\bm{\sigma}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}} and minimize the values of C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} from Theorem 1 and the total privacy leakage given by (19). In this combined formulation, we assume that other FL parameters, such as L,μ,ξ1,ξ2,d,𝐿𝜇subscript𝜉1subscript𝜉2𝑑L,\mu,\xi_{1},\xi_{2},d, and T𝑇T, are constant. The main server can then solve this optimization problem and then broadcast the results to all base stations before Algorithm 1 starts.

Since it is hard to directly solve a multi-objective optimization problem for both scheduling and total privacy leakage, we formulate the problem as a single-objective optimization task as follows:

minimize(𝑹s,𝒑s,𝝈s)s∈𝒮∑s∈𝒮∑i∈𝒰sKs,i​[1−∑n=1Rrs,i(n)]subscriptsubscript𝑹𝑠subscript𝒑𝑠subscript𝝈𝑠𝑠𝒮minimizesubscript𝑠𝒮subscript𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖delimited-[]1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑠𝑖𝑛\displaystyle\underset{(\bm{R}_{s},\bm{p}_{s},\bm{\sigma}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}}}{\text{minimize}}\quad\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}K_{s,i}\bigg{[}1-\sum_{n=1}^{R}r_{s,i}^{(n)}\bigg{]}
+γ​∑s∈𝒮∑i∈𝒰s(1Ks,i​σs,i)2​∑n=1Rrs,i(n)𝛾subscript𝑠𝒮subscript𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠superscript1subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖subscript𝜎𝑠𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑠𝑖𝑛\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad+\gamma\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}\big{(}\frac{1}{K_{s,i}\sigma_{s,i}}\big{)}^{2}\sum_{n=1}^{R}r_{s,i}^{(n)} (20)
subject to
∑s∈𝒮∑i∈𝒰sKs,i​σs,i2​∑n=1Rrs,i(n)≤Vmax​∑s∈𝒮∑i∈𝒰sKs,i​∑n=1Rrs,i(n),subscript𝑠𝒮subscript𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑠𝑖𝑛subscript𝑉subscript𝑠𝒮subscript𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑠𝑖𝑛\displaystyle\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}K_{s,i}\sigma_{s,i}^{2}\sum_{n=1}^{R}r_{s,i}^{(n)}\leq V_{\max}\!\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}K_{s,i}\sum_{n=1}^{R}r_{s,i}^{(n)}, (21)

cs,iU≥Rmin​∑n=1Rrs,i(n),superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑠𝑖Usubscript𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑠𝑖𝑛\displaystyle c_{s,i}^{\mathrm{U}}\geq R_{\min}\sum_{n=1}^{R}r_{s,i}^{(n)}, ∀s∈𝒮,i∈𝒰s,formulae-sequencefor-all𝑠𝒮𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠\displaystyle\forall s\in\mathcal{S},i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}, (26)

where γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 is a constant and is used to balance the optimization of the scheduling and the total privacy leakage. Typically, the value of the constant γ𝛾\gamma can be obtained by hyperparameter tuning and simulations.

Minimizing the first term in the objective function in (20) improves the convergence of Algorithm 1 and is computed by applying (14) to the summation term in C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} of Theorem 1. Minimizing the second term, on the other hand, reduces the total privacy leakage at all users and is given by (19).

Constraint (21) guarantees that the DP noise error, which is characterized by the term C3subscript𝐶3C_{3} of Theorem 1, is less than a given constant Vmaxsubscript𝑉V_{\max}. To derive condition (21), we first consider the following upper bound on the squared term in C3subscript𝐶3C_{3}

(Ks,i​as,iKa​σs,i)2≤Ks,i​as,iKa​σs,i2,superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑠𝑖subscript𝑎𝑠𝑖subscript𝐾asubscript𝜎𝑠𝑖2subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖subscript𝑎𝑠𝑖subscript𝐾asuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠𝑖2\displaystyle\Big{(}\frac{K_{s,i}a_{s,i}}{K_{\mathrm{a}}}\sigma_{s,i}\Big{)}^{2}\leq\frac{K_{s,i}a_{s,i}}{K_{\mathrm{a}}}\sigma_{s,i}^{2}, (27)

which follows by (10) and Ks,i​as,i≤Kasubscript𝐾𝑠𝑖subscript𝑎𝑠𝑖subscript𝐾aK_{s,i}a_{s,i}\leq K_{\mathrm{a}}. Constraint (21) then follows by applying (10) and (14) to this upper bound and setting it to be smaller than Vmaxsubscript𝑉V_{\max}. We can then control the amount of DP noise variance and its error by adjusting the constant Vmaxsubscript𝑉V_{\max}.

Conditions (23)-(24) provide the resource allocation constraints, whereas (25)-(26) restrict the transmit power to a maximum amount Pmaxsubscript𝑃maxP_{\mathrm{max}} and ensure a minimum communication rate Rminsubscript𝑅minR_{\mathrm{min}} for each user in each cell, respectively. Finally, constraint (22) guarantees an upper bound on the privacy leakage of the users individually due to (11). In this case, the constant Nminsubscript𝑁N_{\min} controls the minimum amount of DP noise at each user.

We notice that the variable 𝒂ssubscript𝒂𝑠\bm{a}_{s} and 𝑹ssubscript𝑹𝑠\bm{R}_{s}, which are given by (3) and (13), are related due to (14). Therefore, 𝒂ssubscript𝒂𝑠\bm{a}_{s} does not appear as a minimization variable.

The optimization problem in (20) is not easy to solve. However, we can subdivide it into simpler problems and search for (sub-)optimal solutions. The main server can then compute and broadcast these (sub-)optimal (𝑹s∗,𝒑s∗,𝝈s∗)s∈𝒮subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑹𝑠superscriptsubscript𝒑𝑠superscriptsubscript𝝈𝑠𝑠𝒮(\bm{R}_{s}^{*},\bm{p}_{s}^{*},\bm{\sigma}_{s}^{*})_{s\in\mathcal{S}} to all base stations where they can be forwarded to the users. These computations and initialization should be done prior to the beginning of Algorithm 1.

V Algorithm Design

In this section, we propose two suboptimal sequential algorithms to solve the optimization problem in (20). First, for fixed DP noise the objective function in (20) is minimized with respect to users’ transmit powers and resource block allocation in a cell-by-cell manner. In the second part, with given transmit power and resource block allocation, the optimization problem in (20) becomes convex with respect to the DP noise standard deviations.

V-A Optimal Scheduler

Let the DP noise standard deviations be given such that condition (22) is always satisfied. In the following, we consider the joint transmit power and resource block allocation problem, which is a simplified version of (20).

To solve (30), we assume that (𝑹s~,𝒑s~)s~∈𝒮\{s}subscriptsubscript𝑹~𝑠subscript𝒑~𝑠~𝑠\𝒮𝑠(\bm{R}_{\tilde{s}},\bm{p}_{\tilde{s}})_{\tilde{s}\in\mathcal{S}\backslash\{s\}} are known and satisfy conditions (23)-(25). We then solve this problem with respect to 𝑹ssubscript𝑹𝑠\bm{R}_{s} while taking 𝑹s~subscript𝑹~𝑠\bm{R}_{\tilde{s}} with s~∈𝒮\{s}~𝑠\𝒮𝑠\tilde{s}\in\mathcal{S}\backslash\{s\} as constants. By solving this optimization problem for each cell, we obtain a (sub-)optimal scheduling solution (𝑹s∗)s∈𝒮subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑹𝑠𝑠𝒮(\bm{R}^{*}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}} for the whole system.

In the next step, the optimal transmit powers (𝒑s)s∈𝒮subscriptsubscript𝒑𝑠𝑠𝒮(\bm{p}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}} should be accordingly computed by using (29). Yet, the term ∑s~∈𝒮\{s}Is(n)​(s~)subscript~𝑠\𝒮𝑠superscriptsubscript𝐼𝑠𝑛~𝑠\sum_{\tilde{s}\in\mathcal{S}\backslash\{s\}}I_{s}^{(n)}(\tilde{s}) in (29) is itself a linear function of transmit powers of other users due to (16). In fact, (29) can be written as a linear equation system 𝑨​𝒑=𝒃𝑨𝒑𝒃\bm{Ap}=\bm{b} with unknown variables 𝒑𝒑\bm{p}. In this case, 𝒑𝒑\bm{p} is a vector consisting of all transmit powers ps,isubscript𝑝𝑠𝑖p_{s,i} and 𝑨𝑨\bm{A} and 𝒃𝒃\bm{b} are the coefficients of the linear equation system given by (29). To compute the optimal transmit powers, we solve the following simple optimization:

minimize𝒑‖𝑨​𝒑−𝒃‖1𝒑minimizesubscriptnorm𝑨𝒑𝒃1\displaystyle\underset{\bm{p}}{\text{minimize}}\quad\|\bm{Ap}-\bm{b}\|_{1} (35)
subject to0≤ps,i≤Pmax,∀s∈𝒮,i∈𝒰s.formulae-sequencesubject to0subscript𝑝𝑠𝑖subscript𝑃formulae-sequencefor-all𝑠𝒮𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠\displaystyle\text{subject to}\quad 0\leq p_{s,i}\leq P_{\max},\quad\forall s\in\mathcal{S},i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}.

After finding the optimal powers from (35), we can compute the uplink communication rates by using (18). We then unschedule those users whose rates do not satisfy (26) and set their transmit power to zero.

Based on these solutions, we propose two procedures for user scheduling and DP noise adjustment. Algorithm 2 presents a random scheduler (RndSched). Algorithm 3 provides an optimal scheduler (OptSched) based on (30). Both algorithms benefit from the power allocation procedure based on (35) and both apply random DP noise to achieve privacy.

We note that one advantage of the optimal scheduler is that it is linear and therefore efficient from a practical point of view compared with (28). Nevertheless, the drawback of this approach is that it is performed sequentially and cell by cell. As a result, there is no guarantee that this approach always provides us with an optimal solution. However, as we will see in Subsection VI-A, it delivers very good results compared with the randomized scheduler. In the next subsection, we extend this algorithm to include a DP optimizer.

V-B DP Optimizer

Let the transmit powers and resource block allocation values from the optimal scheduler (𝑹s∗,𝒑s∗)s∈𝒮subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑹𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝒑𝑠𝑠𝒮(\bm{R}^{*}_{s},\bm{p}^{*}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}} be given. The DP noise optimization problem is then given by

For the optimal solution, constraint (21) always holds with equality since the objective function monotonically decreases with increasing σs,isubscript𝜎𝑠𝑖\sigma_{s,i}. Consequently, substituting (38) into (21) with equality implies that

∑s∈𝒮∑i∈𝒰sKs,isubscript𝑠𝒮subscript𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖\displaystyle\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}K_{s,i} ∑n=1Rrs,i(n)​(Ks,i3​κ)−12|Nmin2Ks,i2evaluated-atsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑠𝑖𝑛superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐾𝑠𝑖3𝜅12superscriptsubscript𝑁2superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑠𝑖2\displaystyle\sum_{n=1}^{R}r_{s,i}^{(n)}\left.\left(K_{s,i}^{3}\kappa\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right|_{\frac{N_{\min}^{2}}{K_{s,i}^{2}}}
=Vmax​∑s∈𝒮∑i∈𝒰sKs,i​∑n=1Rrs,i(n).absentsubscript𝑉subscript𝑠𝒮subscript𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑠𝑖𝑛\displaystyle=V_{\max}\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}K_{s,i}\sum_{n=1}^{R}r_{s,i}^{(n)}. (39)

After the value of κ𝜅\kappa is found from (V-B), the optimal σs,i∗subscriptsuperscript𝜎𝑠𝑖\sigma^{*}_{s,i} can be computed from (38). We then combine this scheme with the procedure in Subsection V-A. A summary of this scheme is provided in Algorithm 4 (OptSched+DP).

VI Simulations and Numerical Solutions

VI-A Optimization Problems

In this subsection, we present the numerical solutions of the algorithms that were presented in Section V. In this regard, we apply the Python optimization packages CVXPY, CVXOPT, GLPK, and ECOS [33, 34, 35, 36, 37].

Since Algorithms 3 and 4 are heuristic, their solutions depend on the initial values of the optimizing variables (𝑹s,𝒑s,𝝈s)s∈𝒮subscriptsubscript𝑹𝑠subscript𝒑𝑠subscript𝝈𝑠𝑠𝒮(\bm{R}_{s},\bm{p}_{s},\bm{\sigma}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}} as well as the wireless channels and the number of training samples at each user. As a result, we repeat the computations for several random initial values, channels and data distributions among the users and then compute the average.

To this end, the variables (𝑹s)s∈𝒮subscriptsubscript𝑹𝑠𝑠𝒮(\bm{R}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}} are first initialized based on a shuffled Round-robin scheme and (𝒑s,𝝈s)s∈𝒮subscriptsubscript𝒑𝑠subscript𝝈𝑠𝑠𝒮(\bm{p}_{s},\bm{\sigma}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}} are set uniformly at random such that 0≤ps,i≤Pmax0subscript𝑝𝑠𝑖subscript𝑃0\leq p_{s,i}\leq P_{\max} and Nmin/Ks,i≤σs,i≤6​Nmin/Ks,isubscript𝑁subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖subscript𝜎𝑠𝑖6subscript𝑁subscript𝐾𝑠𝑖N_{\min}/K_{s,i}\leq\sigma_{s,i}\leq 6N_{\min}/K_{s,i} hold. Second, the users are positioned in a square area consisting of seven hexagon cells according to a uniform distribution. The edge devices are then assigned to their nearest base stations according to their random position. Based on their distances to the base stations, their fading channels are then computed by applying (17).

An example of channel initialization, which is generated by our simulator in Python language, is shown in Fig. 3. In this case, the channels between one of the users and base stations are depicted as dashed lines. We notice that the cells 1-6 in this setting can cover users also outside their area while the central cell only covers devices inside the central hexagon. As a result, the effects of boundary and central cells are both taken into account in our simulations.

After the users are assigned to their corresponding base stations, the training data is randomly distributed among all users. Inspired by [48], the number of samples Ks,isubscript𝐾𝑠𝑖K_{s,i} are determined by a lognormal distribution.

Algorithms 3 and 4 should then provide us with (𝑹s∗,𝒑s∗)s∈𝒮subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑹𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝒑𝑠𝑠𝒮(\bm{R}^{*}_{s},\bm{p}^{*}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}} and (𝒂s∗)s∈𝒮subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒂𝑠𝑠𝒮(\bm{a}^{*}_{s})_{s\in\mathcal{S}} which determine (sub-)optimal allocated resource blocks, uplink transmit powers, and the scheduled users.

The system parameters that are used in the computations are listed in Table I. Fig. 4 shows the results of all algorithms in the form of an empirical Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF) of the normalized objective value in (20). The normalization is done by dividing the value of the objective function by the total number of samples (scheduled or unscheduled). The CDF is computed for two values of available number of resource blocks R𝑅R and the optimization constant γ𝛾\gamma from (20) . The results are averaged over 103superscript10310^{3} random channels and initial values. As seen in Fig. 4, the OptSched (Algorithm 3) outperforms the RndSched (Algorithm 2) in terms of minimizing the objective value in (20). Moreover, the OptSched+DP (Algorithm 4) further improves the results of the OptSched by reducing the total privacy leakage. Furthermore, the OptSched+DP achieves lower values for γ=107𝛾superscript107\gamma=10^{7} compared with the case in which γ=106𝛾superscript106\gamma=10^{6}. This is because, larger γ𝛾\gamma in (20) gives more weight to the DP noise optimization.

We also notice that by increasing R𝑅R from 5 to 8, the normalized objective values of the RndSched get slightly closer to the outcome of the OptSched algorithm. This is due to the fact that by increasing R𝑅R and keeping the total number of users constant, chances that all users are successfully scheduled by RndSched become higher. In this case, for large values of R𝑅R, the RndSched might eventually achieves the same performance as for OptSched. However, the choice of selecting a large number of resource blocks for a low number of users is not desirable due to the limited amount of available bandwidth.

VI-B Federated Learning Simulations

In this subsection, we apply the random parameters 𝒂ssubscript𝒂𝑠\bm{a}_{s} and 𝝈ssubscript𝝈𝑠\bm{\sigma}_{s} as well as (sub-)optimal 𝒂s∗subscriptsuperscript𝒂𝑠\bm{a}^{*}_{s} and 𝝈s∗subscriptsuperscript𝝈𝑠\bm{\sigma}^{*}_{s} from Subsection VI-A to an FL system as described in Algorithm 1. In this case, we assume that the main server and all users each maintain a fully connected neural network in the form of a multi-label classifier. The networks consist of two hidden layers, each with 256 nodes. To implement the simulations, we apply the TensorFlow, NumPy, and Matplotlib packages [38, 39, 40]. Furthermore, we use the MNIST image dataset [49] to train and test the multi-label classifier.

In this setting, we train the local models over T=200𝑇200T=200 communication rounds between users and the main server. To follow our mathematical model in Section II, we perform no local iterations and use the batch gradient descent scheme. We do not apply any decay and use a fixed learning rate λ=0.05𝜆0.05\lambda=0.05.

Furthermore, to guarantee that Assumption 1 holds, the gradient of all weights are clipped so that their global norm is smaller than or equal to L=10𝐿10L=10. This directly affects the amount of privacy leakage as given by (11).

We perform the simulations over 100 channels and initial values and then average the resulting accuracy and loss. Furthermore, we generate the empirical CDF of the privacy leakage of all users. Fig. 5 shows the accuracy, loss, and privacy leakage CDF of this learning system for different values of available resource blocks R𝑅R and optimization constant γ𝛾\gamma.

As seen in Fig. 5, the OptSched outperforms the RndSched algorithm in terms of accuracy and loss for both R=5𝑅5R=5 and R=8𝑅8R=8. In this case, the OptSched systematically selects the users with large chunks of data that have a better channel and suffer less from the inter-cell interference. The RndSched algorithm, however, fails in this scenario since it applies a random scheduling scheme.

The OptSched+DP, on the other hand, slightly degrades the performance of the optimal scheduler by increasing and optimizing the DP noise. Yet OptSched+DP provides a similar or even better performance compared with RndSched scheme for small values of R𝑅R (see Figs 5(a) and 5(c)). The degradation is the price that is paid to improve the privacy. Figs. 5(e) and 5(f) show the empirical CDF of the privacy leakage (ρ𝜌\rho). In this case, the value of ρ𝜌\rho at each user is computed by using (11) and the results over all simulation iterations are collected to compute the CDF. The simulations show that the OptSched+DP scheme substantially reduces the amount of privacy leakage at each user. In particular it achieves a maximum privacy leakage of around ρ=0.5𝜌0.5\rho=0.5 thanks to the DP optimizer scheme. This is a significant improvement compared with the RndSched scheme with a maximum leakage of around ρ=4𝜌4\rho=4.

Adjusting the optimization constant γ𝛾\gamma is also crucial. In this regard, by choosing γ=107𝛾superscript107\gamma=10^{7} the OptSched achieves lower privacy leakage compared with γ=106𝛾superscript106\gamma=10^{6} (see Figs. 5(e) and 5(f)). This is because larger γ𝛾\gamma gives less weight to the optimal scheduler in (20) and users with higher DP noise power are preferred in scheduling.

VII Conclusion

In this work, a privacy preserving FL procedure in a multiple base station scenario with inter-cell interference has been considered. An upper bound on the optimality gap of the convergence term of this learning scheme has been derived and an optimization problem to reduce this upper bound has been provided. We have proposed two sequential algorithms to obtain (sub-)optimal solutions for this optimization task; namely an optimal scheduler (OptSched) in Algorithm 3 and its extended version with DP optimizer (OptSched+DP) in Algorithm 4. In designing these schemes we avoid non-linearity in the integer programming problems. The outputs of these algorithms are then applied to an FL system.

Simulation results have shown that the OptSched increases the accuracy of the classification FL system and reduces the loss compared with the RndSched when the number of available resource blocks R𝑅R is small. In this case, when the total number of users is K=100𝐾100K=100 and R=5𝑅5R=5, the OptSched shows an accuracy improvement of over 6%percent66\%. Simulations have further shown that the OptSched not only improves the accuracy but also can reduce the privacy leakage compared with the RndSched if the parameter γ𝛾\gamma is set properly.

The OptSched+DP, on the other hand, further optimizes the DP noise and substantially reduces the privacy leakage compared with both RndSched and OptSched. In this case, simulations have shown that the OptSched+DP reduces the maximum privacy leakage for both R=5𝑅5R=5 and R=8𝑅8R=8 by a factor of 8 (from ρ=4𝜌4\rho=4 to ρ=0.5𝜌0.5\rho=0.5). It is worth mentioning that when R𝑅R is small (e.g. R=5𝑅5R=5), this improvement is achieved while OptSched+DP shows a similar or even better performance in terms of accuracy and loss compared with RndSched.

+d​∑s∈𝒮∑i∈𝒰s(Ks,i​as,iKa​σs,i)2,𝑑subscript𝑠𝒮subscript𝑖subscript𝒰𝑠superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑠𝑖subscript𝑎𝑠𝑖subscript𝐾asubscript𝜎𝑠𝑖2\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\qquad+d\sum_{s\in\mathcal{S}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}_{s}}\bigg{(}\frac{K_{s,i}a_{s,i}}{K_{\mathrm{a}}}\sigma_{s,i}\bigg{)}^{2}, (50)

where the last term in (50) is obtained due to the fact that the random variables ns,i,e(j)superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑠𝑖𝑒𝑗n_{s,i,e}^{(j)} in (49) are independent of each other.

On the other hand, since f𝑓f is μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex (Assumption 4) we have that

‖∇f​(𝒘(t))‖22superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑓superscript𝒘𝑡22\displaystyle\|\nabla f(\bm{w}^{(t)})\|_{2}^{2} ≥2​μ​[f​(𝒘(t))−f​(𝒘∗)].absent2𝜇delimited-[]𝑓superscript𝒘𝑡𝑓superscript𝒘\displaystyle\geq 2\mu\big{[}f(\bm{w}^{(t)})-f(\bm{w}^{*})\big{]}. (51)

By inserting (50) in (47) and using (51), the proof follows. ∎
